title: Boiled Water Video
description:
The video demonstrates a water boiling experiment designed to observe the temperature change and boiling point of water under different atmospheric pressures. The main educational experiment involves heating water in a beaker placed on an electric heater, while monitoring the temperature using two temperature sensors connected to a tablet computer.

Objective: The primary objective is to test and demonstrate the concept of boiling point and how it varies with changes in atmospheric pressure. This experiment can help students understand the relationship between temperature and boiling point, as well as the impact of atmospheric pressure on these physical properties.

Materials and Tools:

Electric heater
Two temperature sensors
Tablet computer
Beaker with cold water
Digital timer
Step-by-Step Procedure:

Set up the experiment by placing the beaker with cold water on the electric heater.
Connect the temperature sensors to the tablet computer, ensuring that sensor 1 measures the temperature of the water, and sensor 2 measures the room temperature (air temperature).
Turn on the data reading function on the tablet and wait for the indicator to stabilize.
Start heating the water by turning on the electric heater.
Record the temperature readings from both sensors over time.
Observe the temperature changes and note when the water begins to boil.
Continue recording until the water reaches its boiling point.
Key Observations:

The temperature of the water increases steadily as it heats up.
Small bubbles appear at the bottom of the beaker as the water approaches its boiling point.
The temperature of the water stabilizes at the boiling point, which is recorded as 212 degrees Fahrenheit in this experiment.
Conclusions:

The boiling point of water is 212 degrees Fahrenheit at standard atmospheric pressure.
At a higher altitude, the atmospheric pressure is lower, resulting in a lower boiling point. In this experiment, the boiling point was observed to be 202.4 degrees Fahrenheit when the atmospheric pressure was 8001 pascals.
Safety Measures and Important Notes:

Ensure that the experiment is conducted in a well-ventilated area to avoid any potential hazards from steam or hot water.
Use appropriate safety gear, such as gloves and goggles, when handling hot equipment and liquids.
Always follow proper laboratory protocols and safety guidelines when conducting experiments.
Learning Outcomes and Real-World Applications:

Students will gain a practical understanding of the relationship between temperature and boiling point.
They will learn how atmospheric pressure affects the boiling point of water, which is crucial in various real-world applications, such as cooking at high altitudes or understanding the behavior of water in different environments.
The experiment also teaches students about the importance of accurate measurement and observation in scientific research.

title: Temperature
description:
This video demonstrates an experiment to test the reliability of human temperature perception using both hands. The objective is to show that temperature perception can be unreliable and varies from person to person.

The materials used in this experiment include three beakers filled with water at different temperatures (ice water, room temperature water, and hot water), a tablet displaying a graph to record temperature readings, and a stopwatch for timing.

The step-by-step procedure involves placing one hand on the beaker with ice water and the other hand on the beaker with hot water. Participants are instructed to hold their hands in these positions for one minute to allow their hands to adjust to the temperatures. After one minute, they are asked to switch their hands so that the left hand is now in the hot water and the right hand is in the cold water. The participants then record the perceived temperature of each hand.

Key observations from the video include the initial temperature readings displayed on the tablet, which show the beakers containing ice water at 42.7°F, room temperature water at 78.2°F, and hot water at 121.2°F. As the experiment progresses, the participants' perceptions of the temperature change, with the left hand perceiving the hot water as warm and the right hand perceiving the cold water as cool. This highlights the unreliability of human temperature perception.

Conclusions drawn from the experiment indicate that temperature perception can vary significantly from person to person and that it is not always accurate. The experiment also emphasizes the importance of conducting multiple trials to obtain reliable data.

Safety measures or important notes include ensuring that the hot water is not too hot to avoid burns and that participants follow proper procedures when handling the beakers and water.

Learning outcomes from this experiment include understanding the concept of temperature perception and its variability among individuals. It also teaches the importance of conducting multiple trials to obtain reliable data and emphasizes safety precautions when working with hot liquids.

title: Ice
description: This experiment investigates whether the temperature of an object depends on its size by comparing a whole ice block with crushed ice. Using sensors and tablets, students observe that temperature remains consistent despite differences in ice size. The experiment introduces concepts of heat transfer and the independence of temperature from object size, reinforcing the scientific method and safe handling of equipment.

title: Cold and Hot Water
description: This experiment explores how the temperature of a mixture changes when hot and cold water are combined. With digital tools and careful measurement, students observe that the resulting temperature is not simply the average of the two initial temperatures. It introduces specific heat capacity, principles of heat transfer, and reinforces data-driven conclusions through visual graphing tools.

title: Melted Ice
description: This experiment examines temperature behavior during the melting of ice. By placing a test tube with ice into room-temperature water and monitoring changes with sensors and a graphing tablet, students observe initial slight increases, temperature plateaus during phase change, and eventual rises. The experiment emphasizes phase change dynamics, energy absorption, and the importance of steady observation and controlled environments.
